Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned the basics about kinematics, gravity, rotational motion, and other introductory physics topics.
Insight into basic physics concepts and problem solving strategies.
How to approach physics problems from a clear theoretical groundwork and apply it to creative problems.
I built upon my problem solving abilities and learned calculus based physics.
DEFINITELY a great course for students getting into physics. Steinacker is very good at explaining material fairly simply.
Physics 180 has dusted off my memories from high school physics, added a layer of  calculus to that knowledge, and challenged me to approach new kinds of problems and a new way of thinking.
Got a good sense of introductory physics, specifically in mechanics.

This was a great course that covered a lot of good content. The course focuses on the standard principles of mechanics, including kinematics, energy, relative motion, gravity, torque, waves, harmonic motion, etc. The course used a calculus approach (mostly calc 2 with some calc 3), which for me was a more challenging but also a more insightful way to learn physics.
I learned many physics concepts and formulas.

Where do I begin? There was so much material packed into this course, and Prof. Steinacker tried to show us the beauty of interpreting the physical world. I feel as though I can better handle physical problems, and I think this was certainly an introduction to these ideas.
basic physics concepts
I learnt to think critically and also to solve questions with other students. The study hall sessions was an opportunity to meet other students who shared my interest in STEM.

The course was similar in material to AP Physics C in high school, but certain topics were further explored, such as gravitation and simple harmonic motion.  The class thoroughly went through the basic elements of physics using calculus.  The p-sets can be a bit long and difficult, but helpful.
How to do psets
The course teaches an amazing amount of physics with extreme clarity and precision developed by Steinacker.
This course was a fantastic introduction to Physics. It showed how beautiful and clever of a subject Physics is.
I learned physics concepts and how to apply them to problems. I also gained insight on different ways to approach solving such problems.
I learned a great amount of knowledge in mechanics, kinematics, and gravity.

The fundamentals of physics are taught. There are some pretty cool concepts. Did you know that if you sit on a spinny chair and spin one way while holding a spinning wheel and you flip the spinning wheel, you'll start spinning the other way? I also learned why, if you spin a lazy susan fast enough, all the stuff on top flies off. And why cats always land on their feet!
Basic physics knowledge
A good survey of the mechanics portion of physics. Comparable material to the AP Physics C class if you have taken it.
I had taken Physics in high school, but this class was much more organized and I feel I gained an appreciation for a style of doing the work, even if I had learned much of the material prior.
I learned a deep understanding of mechanics of physics. I also learned the power of teamwork and collaboration.

This course definitely stretched my mind and tested my mathematical skills. Professor Steinacker is absolutely incredible and is passionate about teaching physics, and is always cracking jokes during lecture to keep students attentive. She answers questions comprehensively; however, she will not simply give away answers, she makes you work for them. I really enjoyed this course and think I developed a much stronger grasp on physics throughout the semester.

I learned basic mechanics. I'd had two years of physics in high school (including AP physics), so I was familiar with the concepts, but that doesn't mean I didn't learn/expand upon skills. This class is HARD. I learned a lot about problem solving I guess and like the general techniques required to do physics. There were some types of problems that I hadn't done before, like the rocket problems.
Before this course, I couldn't derive anything to save my life.  Now I am comfortable (or at least pretend to be) with deriving equations on the fly (aka during finals)
I learned calculus-based mechanics.

I learned how to think through a problem, decide which pieces of information were important, and apply the correct equations and concepts to answer the question. I have a deeper understanding of basic physics and I feel able to apply the concepts I have learned to simple real world problems.
180 gives you a good overview of calculus-based mechanics. Math is integrated into all the psets and you get to understand real-world applications for these topics.
How to approach problems in a structured way, and how to think critically when approaching problems.

I gained a deeper understanding of many mechanistic concepts underlying physical phenomena as well as an interest in their applications. I also learned how wonderful other students can be in helping to wrap my head around these concepts through mass group work on PSets.

I learned about Newtonian mechanics, thermodynamics, gravitation, and waves and acquired skills in problem-solving challenging questions that apply concepts learned in lecture. I gained insight into how physics is used in the real world and how to approach problems in a methodical and logical way.
Basics of Physics. Pretty cool stuff but nothing particularly world-changing.
I gained a more thorough understanding of basic mechanics, as well as greater confidence in my physical intuition and quantitative reasoning skills.

PHYS 180 was good overview of mechanics. I took AP Physics C in high school, which covered the same subjects. However, PHYS 180 went into significantly more depth, and I have a much better understanding of mechanics. This course required a lot of math, ranging from advanced algebra to integral calculus (e.g. Taylor series). I have not taken any math since first semester at Yale, so I found PHYS 180 to be a good review of mathematical techniques.

I gained a much greater understanding of the ways in which physics is used in a variety of different professions. I am now able to answer complex physics problems, describe physical systems mathematically and qualitatively, and explain my understanding of the physical world.
Problem-solving and seeing the physics behind everyday phenomena

I received a general introduction to classical physics. More importantly, I think, I improved a lot in my ability to think critically and solve problems, knowledge that is always useful in approaching a new situation.
Typical mechanics course with an emphasis on problem solving and intersection between different mechanics concepts.
I learned how to solve physics problems very well and expanded my knowledge on the subject greatly.
Great intuition for understanding the physical world around us.
This course taught me the important, fundamental concepts of intro physics.
I learned mechanical physics, as I thought I would. You go far beyond high school level physics, and the class truly teaches you to apply physics.

I grew in my understanding of physics, not only in the mechanical sense, but also as it applies to other scientific and mathematic disciplines. Physics was made to be very applicable to many different types of problems.
Problem solving and thinking about the natural world.
Basic mechanics, problem solving skills, applications of higher-level math and physics concepts
I learned all about kinematics, rotation, gravitation, intertia, and how to piece many of these concepts together to solve complex problems.
Intro to mechanics: kinetics, work, energy, forces, torques, momentum
I learned the application of claculus based Newtonian Mechanics
This course built upon my understanding of physics (specifically mechanics), taking it from the algebra-based fundamentals to the calculus-based details.

This course taught the basics physics of motion, including linear, rotational, and oscillatory motion. It also helped me learn how to apply math to real life situations and improved my ability to integrate. Finally, i learned to interpret differential equations better.
Learned about basic mechanics and how physics is applied in daily life. Especially learned important problem solving skills that can be applied to any situations in quantitative reasoning.
considering this was my first time taking physics and a very heavy algebra  based science, it really improved my skills.

I learned about physics topics including kinematics, kinetic and some types of potential energy, forces, torque, moments of inertia, centers of mass, rotational kinematics, and waves. All with calculus. I think I got better at some of the tricky math and problem-solving.
The class was useful in developing math skills and learning physics concepts.

This class is honestly just poorly put together, the material in class is presented as simply as possible yet the homeworks are impossible to the point of not being able to complete them without office hours, which is not really how an introductory course should be.
The course moved at a fast but reasonable pace. Lots of help was available which was nice but sometimes the TAs weren't that knowledgeable in helping us with specific questions.

Problem sets were very collaborative and encouraged working with others, something I generally do not do for homework assignments. Although they were hard, they offered a thorough investigation into the topics we were learning.

Includes useful demonstrations both through movie clips and through traditional physics systems such as the pulley that supplement lecture. Problem sets challenge learning and encourages working as a team.

I think the main strength of this class is that Professor Steinacker makes it very achievable to do well, but she doesn't sacrifice rigor or intensity in the process. You have to put in a ton of work, but you feel like it pays off. You probably should go to office hours/the tutors regularly. They're super helpful and necessary unless you're a genius.

The only weakness of this course may be the lecture setting, in which it feels difficult to ask questions, but besides that, this course is designed to help students succeed, which I very much appreciate.  The professor is very devoted to helping her students.

Strength is also its weakness. The homework can be ridiculous. I found myself going to study hall and just getting the answers from people who got hints from the professor. Really hurt my critical thinking skills in that aspect. To be fair there are some questions you just CANT solve without knowing what math-wizard trick she means for you to use, necessitating the study hall/collaboration. Just try to resist the temptation to get the answers and make yourself grind through it by yourself as much as possible. It will hurt but it'll be worth it.

The strength of this course is Professor Steinacker. I've never seen a professor put so much time and effort into her students. She comes to class with her lectures clear and well-organized, but more than that, she spends countless hours during the week making herself available for questions. 

I think a few things that could be improved are the way new materials are introduced. If I hadn't had high school physics, I would find the new topics extremely difficult to follow, because we often jump straight into more difficult pieces of it. I also think the psets can be unnecessarily difficult at times, offering algebraic tricks without really gaining new knowledge.
Steinacker is great and does a wonderful job teaching the material. She wants you to do well and will personally try to make sure you do.
There were so many opportunities to get help, really great because of that.

Strengths: The professor is for sure the biggest strength of the course. Adriane Steinacker is the BEST professor that I have ever had, or will ever have, at this university. Her lectures are so clear and concise. She makes a point to hand write every lecture on the board, so you can easily follow along and so she can explain everything herself. THEN, she posts very in-depth lecture notes for each class so you can go back and review each class. She holds offie hours like literally every day, and is VERY accessible for all students to meet at any time. Any time there is a problem in grading or anything like that, she is very quick to respond and fix the problem. She grades the course very fairly and makes it open and fair for everyone.

Weaknesses: The problem sets, while helpful, are both long and incredibly difficult, taking up to 14 hours each week. I'm glad this was my only course with psets this semester, because these are easily 2 courses work of problems each week. There are a lot of resources for you to get help on them, though.
The workload is very high but the professor has so many office hours and the TAs have so many study halls that it is manageable.
Honestly, so many opportunities for help are available with this course that I can't in good conscience complain.

Strengths: Achieve a good understanding of Mechanics, very good instructor, plenty of opportunities to seek help outside of class, material that will be on the MCAT

Weaknesses: PSETs are a little hard some weeks

Psets are SO much work!!! I spent around 8 hours during 5 or 6 problems on average and so people spent much much more!

Lectures are not helpful at all - Steinacker may be the nicest person in the world during office hours, but it doesn't change the fact that she is a horrible lecturer. She tries to derive things only to confuse people even more. At least she sometimes tells good jokes and shows cool physics clips. People who are good at physics and those who are not good are equally confuzzled by what she is saying. Also, since there is a participation grade, you are forced to go to class even though, at least for me, it was kind of a waste of time...

That being said, I would say it is difficult to do well in this class if you've never taken physics before. The material is presented poorly, the psets are too difficult to help you master basic content, and the exams are HARD. I've taken physics extensively before in high school, and I probably did well. HOWEVER, stuff was just so unnecessarily complicated and I spent a LOT of time. For me, the exams were kind of fun (like it's a fun puzzle to figure out what the questions are asking!!) but most people probably don't think that way because the averages for the 2 midterms were like 70 ish. Some of the final questions were also kind of brutal honestly - if I hadn't seen them before, I would have no clue what they were getting at.

That being said, apparently Steinacker is a saint who will help you a lot in office hours. I never went...so I wouldn't know, but knowing that there is support from the professor is great, of course.

I think the class is well-taught and the review sessions were particularly useful for the exams. I believe the notes on canvas were clear and easily accessible. However, I believe that the psets are way to long and challenging sometimes. However, I was impressed with the exam corrections which help boost our grade but on the other hand I don't think the grade after the exam corrections are a true reflection of our understanding and level of engagement with the material studied. I don't know what can be done about this because on one hand it is useful but on the other hand, it gives a false sense of accomplishment.

The strengths of this course are that there are many places to get help if you are struggling with the material and that the course has a relatively slow pace, so falling behind shouldn't be too much of an issue.  The weakness is that the p-sets are sometimes a degree of difficulty beyond what is covered in class.
The lecture style is a little difficult to understand

The strengths of this course is that Professor Steinacker is the most amazing professor I have ever had at Yale. Even though the exams and psets are extremely difficult, the amount of support that Adrianne Steinacker provides is amazing. Nothing could be improved upon more besides getting a better set of TAs to grade more uniformly on the problem sets.

This course requires a lot of work and time. You must be willing to go to office hours and really learn the material. You have to constantly stay on top of material, but it is all worth it. This course makes the learning validating and satisfying.

Professor Steinacker is an incredible instructor and really goes out of her way, both in lecture and outside of lecture, to encourage learning. However, the content itself is difficult, as are the homework sets, which can be overwhelming. That being said, the course itself is well taught.
I felt like feedback on homework and tests was really inconsistent and sometimes untimely.
A strength of this course is surely Professor Steinacker who is a coherent professor who understands student's issues in physics well.

Strengths: It gets the job done, and Professor Steinacker sets up a very strong support system for those who care to use it. She's also very nice and willing to explain things. 
Weaknesses: The course at some points becomes essentially manipulations of algebra; I would've liked to see more conceptual physics. Also, my TA was extremely unresponsive to both emails and comments on canvas.
Very challenging no criticisms
The problem sets were long but doable because Adriane and her teaching fellows were so incredible. There were office hours every weekday and study hall every night.

I feel that the challenge of the PSets helped with my understanding of the material, although the size of the class made it somewhat difficult to gain a significant amount from actual lecture time.  Peer tutor hours were especially helpful.

Strengths: The course is explanatory and everything connects very nicely.

Weaknesses: The TA's aren't always equal in grading, but as long as you talk to the professor about it, it will get corrected.

By far the largest strength of this class is the professor. Her lectures are wonderful and her tests are comprehensive, even if they are difficult. The problem sets are also tricky and can take quite a bit of time, but are good preparation for exams. A weakness of the course would have to be the difficulty of the problems as compared to the underlying concepts; however, I also view this as a strength.

The class notes, study halls, and peer tutors were strengths of this course. The p-sets took a lot of time and were not always connected to lectures. The teaching fellows were not very present except to help in study hall. Having optional or mandatory discussion sections similar to the intro chemistry sequences could be helpful in developing student connections to a specific TA who could aid in better understanding of the material outside of strictly homework help.

This course is very well taught and structured. All of the class notes (which are incredibly thorough and well developed) are posted to the class canvas section, which very much facilitates catching up on material if one misses something during lecture or is unable to attend class. The grading policy of the course is very clearly delineated at the beginning of the semester and Professor Steinacker emphasizes learning physics for the opportunity of learning rather than for fulfilling a prerequisite. While this class is probably required for anyone taking it, it could probably not be better than with Professor Steinacker. Her compassion and interest in the topics genuinely makes class as enjoyable as it could be, and she is incredibly fair and willing to help students. The fact that there are so many office hours and resources makes the difficult material easier to handle.

This class is just so much work. It is frustrating in a way because if you are a normal person like me, you probably can't really do any of the PSET on your own. This means you have to spend your LIFE in office hours and study hall. I didn't ask for that. I am only taking this class because I'm premed. I'm not going to be a physicist and I think it's a ridiculous amount of work for someone who knows that. I understand that I need to learn physics, but I spent literally all of my free time in office hours and study hall. Every free moment when I wasn't in class I was there. It's frustrating that the PSETs are simply un-doable alone. Too time consuming. 

That said, Professor Steinacker is so lovely. She's a lovely person, so sweet, SO committed to her students, more than any other intro STEM professor I've had. Even though she has like 300 students she knows everyone's name! I really do appreciate that. She is a great professor too and teaches the material very well. I love her class notes online. They help so much.

I think many people like this course because of the instructor. It is  a lecture course, and the professor holds office hours everyday; further review can be done at study hall. However, this class is definitely very difficult for students that have either never taken physics, or have trouble thinking about physics in the way in requires (two categories in which I fall into). Don't get me wrong, I learned a lot, but I put so much effort into this class and it was still very difficult to keep up.

This class NEEDS a discussion section, like chemistry. I know it is a big course and perhaps there are a lack of TAs, but this class seriously needs one for people like me. Course material is covered very quickly and the questions on the psets are very difficult. Please, please, please form a discussion section for this class. That way, I don't have to wait for the instructor's attention at office hours (which is literally always crowded). In all honestly, while the peer tutors are helpful, it is evident that they are not taught how to teach, and sometimes, them helping just got me more confused because they either had to backtrack their explanations or just read off the answer key.
The strength of this course is the professor. She lets the students to concentrate on the learning itself.
Course material is covered very quickly, so an outline of the exact topics with corresponding textbook chapters would be a helpful reference upon which to look back during midterms/finals.

Strengths: Prof. Steinacker is amusing and very enthusiastic, and she cares about her students. Her exam review sessions are helpful, and her exams are mostly fair. The frequent study halls are great because students can work on problem sets collaboratively and receive guidance from peer tutors and teaching fellows.

Weaknesses: Sometimes it's hard to focus during a long lecture with many students, and the collected classwork is rushed. The material often relies on mathematical skills and intuition that many students are still developing, so those students were confused at times. The textbook isn't very good, Prof. Steinacker's lecture notes are lengthy, and at first it wasn't clear what resources were available on Canvas. The problem sets are very time-consuming, they weren't graded timely, and only some of the questions counted.

The course could be improved by addressing the weaknesses outlined above, such as by dividing the class into smaller sections, by changing the textbook, and by giving credit for all of the assigned homework problems.

This course moved quickly but was structured very well structured. The lectures were very clear and the weekly problem sets helped solidify and expand my understanding of the topics covered in class. I think this course was great and there isn't much room for improvement.

I believe this course could benefit from sticking to a textbook a little more closely. For exams, you have to study from the pset and lectures, which are extremely detailed that you can sometimes lose sight of the larger ideas in physics.
 I enjoy and respect that Steinacker challenges us to think more critically. However, oftentimes the material is unnecessarily challenging. 
The peer tutoring program was amazing for this course. I got so much help from them and the course needs to continue this program.

The strength of this course if the enthusiasm and kindness of the professor. The main weakness is the manner in which the material is taught. Lectures are largely focused on proofs of equations rather than examining a broad array of situations we could use the equations in.
The workload in the class is difficult, but if you stick through and do it you will end up learning a great deal about physics.

This physics class made physics seem possible for me. The greatest strength are the psets. They allow you to create relationship with Professor Steinacker ad your peers. If you take them seriously, you are forced to engage with the material and really learn key ideas. Class time is not that intereasting, because it is still physics. However, Steinacker makes the best of it.

The course is incredibly well taught with clear expectations that match the material covered. It also allows for an extensive interaction with peers over PSets, which I found to be very valuable. The PSets are long, but they are approachable thanks to Dr. Steinacker.

Two strengths of this course are the weekly problem sets that keep you on top of the material and Prof. Steinacker's ability to clearly communicate concepts during lecture with enthusiasm and attention to any confusion among students.

This was a very good introductory course. The strengths were almost always related to Professor Steinacker's skill as an educator. That being said, the class was stressful, moreso than most introductory courses. The psets were long and difficult, but did help you master the material. Professor Steinacker also gave us seemingly endless opportunities to get help.

Prof. Steinacker is very enthusiastic about the subject, which made it easier to engage myself with the lectures. She has always been very clear when explaining concepts and walking through problems.

The difficulty of the problem sets made this course quite stressful at times. Extensive amounts of creativity and endurance were required for the problem sets. But this was expected since the beginning, and the problem sets are what made this course intellectually challenging and rewarding. Office hours were very helpful as well, but perhaps a few more hints could be added to the most difficult problems to reduce stress.

The greatest strength of this course was Professor Steinacker. She is by far the best professor I have had at Yale thus far, and is clearly dedicated 110% to the course and her students. She went far about and beyond what was required to ensure we all had an incredible experience.

This class is excellent. Strengths include no requirement of previous physics; enough challenge that everyone must work (regardless of background); clear and helpful professor; interesting lectures; a good curve; and a vast array of resources to help on problem sets. One potential weakness is that sometimes the problem sets felt a little bit algebraically intense (there was often a algebraic "trick" necessary to solve the problem that did not relate to the physics of the problem). Of course, this might be necessary for any number of reasons (thinking of good homework problems is hard, these sorts of algebraic tricks are useful for the engineers in the class, these sorts of algebraic tricks are considered an important part of a physics education), and, given the excellent peer tutors, is not a big deal. One other potential weakness is that the the peer tutors gave inconsistent amounts of help -- some would essentially write out the solution with you (too much help), others would give just very basic, general advice (too little help), and some (my favorite) would give the perfect amount of help, usually helping us to set up the problem but leaving us to work through it ourselves (but being there to help more/problem solve if we get stuck). More standardization across peer tutors would be great, but I know this is difficult.

This course is amazing! It is taught in an extremely engaging manner, Professor Steinacker manages to keep it very interactive despite the large class size. All concepts were elaborated on very explicitly with examples and repeated when necessary. The HWs were challenging but Professor Steinacker always made herself available to help.
Strengths: Professor Steinacker, tons of office hour times, corrections
The weekly psets are a huge strength -- keeps you on top of your game!
It's a great course largely because of the teacher. It's just difficult material, especially if you don't have experience in physics.

I think the strengths are the topics that this course covers, however, I felt as though the lectures moved very quickly. Additionally, the amount of resources that are available to students to work on the homework or for additional help are great!

The lectures are very interesting, but they are too fast paced and do not start with the basics. It would be more helpful to start with a basic problem / just going over the very simply stuff, and then going into the more advanced topics. Also, the PSets are far too long and take 5-10 hours. I learned a lot from the PSets, but they could be shorter.

The course has a great instructor, but some of the topics are not sufficiently explained between the notes, the book, and the problems. I think it would be helpful to have a textbook that properly corresponds with the notes and the in class lecture.

The problem sets were quite challenging but that makes sense so that the exam can be broader. I liked how they therefore counted for a lot of our grades since they took up a lot of time. I generally liked the structure of the course and wouldnt change much.
They provide so many resources for you to succeed
-The psets were sometimes so difficult that I felt like I was missing out on learning the more basic content

Exams were representational of psets, which I really appreciated. However, I felt that the psets could sometimes be unnecessarily long, taking upwards of eight conglomerate hours to complete. I understand the importance of practicing the ideas presented in lecture, but pset problems were sometimes contrived and overly complex. Aside from that, I felt that the subject material was presented clearly, and additional resources were extremely accessible.

This course did a great job teaching physics. The problem sets and examples were very helpful both for gaining an intuition for the problems as well as for understanding the math. That being said, I often felt lectures could have been structured in a way as to make concepts easier to understand. This could have been achieved, for example, by placing more emphasis on key ideas/equations. It would have been helpful if professor Steinacker had written out key definitions (e.g. torque, velocity, vector, etc.) and boxed key equations. Furthermore, I would have liked a brief summary of key previous lecture at the beginning of every new lecture. Finally, it would have been helpful if the first lecture of the semester gave a more general overview of what physics is and how math is used in it (e.g. why are derivatives important??).

The course was very well organized because there were plenty of study halls and office hours one can get support from. The lectures are well supplemented with good lecture notes and Adriane is a gem truly.
I felt it was sometimes hard to understand concepts and relations between concepts because I was so focused on the math.
Course has helpful office hours and study halls. However, if you have never taken physics before, the lecture are difficult to follow/keep up with.

The course's strength was the professor because she was very engaging and did a lot to ensure students were enjoying physics. The  only weakness were the problem sets. They could be improved by providing answers to the practice problems to know whether or not students understand the material. Also, it feels unfair to do all the problems and then only have a few graded.
If you have to take it, take it with Adriene Steinacker. She is one of the most incredible STEM professors I have ever had and you will learn so much.

If you're taking 180 you have to take 180, but honestly try and avoid taking it with Steinacker, everyone loves her because she is nice and has office hours everyday, but you will be at those office hours everyday with the difficult and often irrelevant homework she gives. To be fair, she sometimes offers hints on some of the problems, but for the most part you can't solve them without office hours, which is ridiculous for an introductory course. The exams are easy and there are test corrections, so it really doesn't make sense for the homeworks to be horrifying every week, especially when you will inevitably be in harder classes with workloads that are justifiably large.
I would recommend this course, simply because this is a useful class for whatever field you are entering in terms of giving you skills to problem solve.
Yes if at all interested. Psets required a lot of time but were rewarding.
So easy, could be your sixth class
I would recommend this course. The professor is great and you definitely learn over the semester.
Yes.  This class trains people to be problem solvers, which is a dying skill in a world in which we can rely on computers for answers.
Yes! If you can take this with Professor Steinacker, absolutely.
180 is great. Steinacker is very good at her job and the workload is manageable.
Yes definitely do it if you need to take Physics, would argue that this is better than 170/171 even if you are pre-med.
I would recommend this course to any student who is truly interested in traditional physics. There were not many real-life or practical problems, which I did not enjoy.

Most students who take physics don't have the choice. However, you do get to chose which physics class specifically. I know that most people will be decided between 180 and 170, like I was and many other premeds do. While I do believe that 170 is probably more relevant to the MCAT and for medicine in general, and that its content is probably more engaging if you're not really interested in classical physics, I would warrant you to weigh your choices. 180 was a bit more mathy than 170, sure, but Steinacker is hands down the best professor I have ever had and she made physics as painless and interested as it could possibly be for a premed. She is by far much more valuable than any medically relevant content they might cover in 170. I'm really, really glad that I took this over 170!
I would recommend it to another student if it would be a useful class to them, but maybe not as a "for fun" course because of the high workload.
As far as physics classes go, one could not ask for a more engaging teacher.
I would recommend this course to a nother student.

Psets are SO much work!!! I spent around 8 hours during 5 or 6 problems on average and so people spent much much more!

Lectures are not helpful at all - Steinacker may be the nicest person in the world during office hours, but it doesn't change the fact that she is a horrible lecturer. She tries to derive things only to confuse people even more. At least she sometimes tells good jokes and shows cool physics clips. People who are good at physics and those who are not good are equally confuzzled by what she is saying. Also, since there is a participation grade, you are forced to go to class even though, at least for me, it was kind of a waste of time...

That being said, I would say it is difficult to do well in this class if you've never taken physics before. The material is presented poorly, the psets are too difficult to help you master basic content, and the exams are HARD. I've taken physics extensively before in high school, and I probably did well. HOWEVER, stuff was just so unnecessarily complicated and I spent a LOT of time. For me, the exams were kind of fun (like it's a fun puzzle to figure out what the questions are asking!!) but most people probably don't think that way because the averages for the 2 midterms were like 70 ish. Some of the final questions were also kind of brutal honestly - if I hadn't seen them before, I would have no clue what they were getting at.

That being said, apparently Steinacker is a saint who will help you a lot in office hours. I never went...so I wouldn't know, but knowing that there is support from the professor is great, of course. 

Overall, despite this long-winded answer, I'm not sure what my answer would be. For me, personally, I wish I had taken physics 200.
yes, its a very well taught course, with really reasonable grading. i thought the lectures were clear and cohesive especially for people without physics backgrounds
Yes I would recommend this class to other students. It is intellectually stimulating but be prepared to spend 10+ hours on the weekly problem sets.

I would recommend this course, as it will definitely teach you a basic knowledge of physics which can be helpful in many places.  Also, the grading system is not harsh, so you will not be penalized if physics is not your strength.
Only if you need to take it.

Take this course over PHYS 170. Steinacker is the most amazing professor you will ever have at Yale. She spends tons of hours every week to ensure that everyone can do the problem sets and feels good going into the exams. Be warned: the problem sets can take up to 14 hours a week, the exams are some of the most difficult I've taken at Yale, and the content is comprehensive and not just catered to one group (sorry pre-meds - take 170 if you hate physics and just want coverage for the MCAT). However, all of this is worth it because Steinacker is an amazing professor. Seriously, take it! You might have to work hard, but it's worth it. I would say if you are deciding between 170 and 180 (and maybe even 200), take 180 because Steinacker is the best.
Absolutely! Put in the time, but it will feel great.

I would only recommend this course to students who are either really interested in physics (and willing to put in the work) or to students who have to take it. It's a huge amount of work and is seriously difficult, although Professor Steinacker is wonderful and does a good job organizing the course material.
I would recommend this course to another student. It is an excellent introduction to physics in university.

I would absolutely recommend this course for students with little to no experience in physics, and honestly, physics is the way the world we live in works, so it's beneficial to understand it to some degree. That being said, I came in having taken AP Physics C three years ago and found it slightly on the more boring side. Students who have experience and who are actually interested in more conceptual material should probably take the 200 or 260 sequence.
Yes very challenging and fun
Take this over 170. Steinacker is incredible and it will be so worth it.
Yes.  The class is interesting and Prof. Steinacker kept lectures interesting even with how many people were present.
Yes.

I would recommend this course to another student. Although it is a lot of work, the amount of time spent on homework is fairly represented in your grade and there are many office hours to make sure you understand the material. Also, between all of the students enrolled in the class you really get a deep understanding of the materials.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The professor is amazing and there are test corrections that enable you to get some points back on tests, which definitely helps your grade. The workload is significant and Professor Steinacker makes the material difficult; however, you will come out of the class with a much deeper understanding of physics than you otherwise would in a different course.

I don't know...I'd kind of say only take it if you have to. You're in for a LOT of work. You will probably learn a lot though...you're kind of forced to the way the class is structured. Steinacker is lovely, so that's a plus!

It's a requirement for a lot of STEM majors, but no. I recommend this course if you are going to Credit/D it because you are legitimately interested, you are actually good at physics, and because it is still better than PHYS 170. But overall... no.

This course is not easy, and it does take up a fairly significant amount of time, especially the weekly psets. With that said, I would definitely recommend this course. It's so well taughtProfessor Steinacker is so passionate about the subject and excited to teach it, which really makes a difference. Her lectures are clear and engaging, and the lecture notes she posts after every class are extremely helpful for review and extra support on tricky concepts. Her office hours are also great. She is so friendly, always willing to help with anything. She also knows almost everyone's names, which is impressive in such a large course! I came into this course having never taken physics before, and I now feel I have a strong understanding of the fundamentals.

This course is basically AP Physics 1, but crammed into one semester and much more in depth, with a lot more derivation and calculus involved.  Although the course was rather tricky at times, it's not terribly difficult if you read the textbook in conjunction with the lectures, and go to office hours if need be.  The lectures are very engaging, and there is only one problem set a week.  Whether you are interested in physics or just need to take it as a prerequisite, I would recommend this course.

I would recommend this course to students who are somewhat familiar with physics and calculus. The highest-level physics and math classes available at my high school were AP Physics 1 (which is algebra-based) and AP Calculus AB, respectively, but they definitely helped me understand the material in PHYS 180.

This is a great introductory physics course if you are considering majoring in a STEM field that will require you to know a good amount of physics. The material and workload are challenging, but the class is very rewarding because it is taught and structured so well. I would recommend this to anyone majoring in a field related to physics.
Professor Steinacker does an amazing job and clearly cares about the well-being of her students. Would recommend
I would recommend this course to another student if they have a lot of free time to spend in office hours.
Yes!

I think 180 is a good class to take if you're interested in physics and want a good foundation in it. The class has a good pace with relevant real world examples. Psets can be a bit tedious, but  through office hours or working with friends you get to really recognize the beauty of a lot of physics problems. Professor Steinacker is amazing and is so considerate when helping students.
If you have to take physics, take it with Steinacker. She is an amazing professor, and she makes the difficult material manageable.
I recommend the teacher and her teaching strategy. Most people are in this class because they have to take it.
This course take a lot of work, but I definitely recommend it with a good professor (such as Steinacker) because you genuinely get a deep understanding and appreciation of what you're learning.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The lectures were fascinating and Prof. Steinacker really cares about her students. It's very easy to listen to Prof. Steinacker lecture the class, as she has a calming, motivational voice that made learning new physics concepts both enjoyable and painless.

I would absolutely recommend this course. People give it a bad rap and our scared to take it. To be clear, yes, the workload and intellectual challenge is intense. But this is a class where if you put in the work (office hours, study hall, etc) you will see positive results. Challenge yourself and take this course, you will find it very rewarding.

Yes, actually! I would. You learn a lot of physics and feel really good about it at the end. The exams were always very stressful for me, but there are only three of them so... The psets force you to get help and work with others, allowing you to make lots of physics friends!

If you're interested in physics (or science in general), and don't have a strong physics background, I recommend PHYS 180. However, make sure you don't take too many hard classes at the same time because the p-sets will take a long time--they can range from 5 hours to 15 hours. I took organic chemistry and the intro bio sequence at the same time as PHYS 180, and I struggled a little in managing my time. It's absolutely essential that you are able to dedicate time for the p-sets (they're due on Friday, but many people start around Monday). But besides the p-sets, it's a very good course. You will learn intro physics very well, and you will develop problem solving skills. Plus, Prof. Steinacker is great!

If you need to take physics (pre-med, engineering, etc), PLEASE TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! It is definitely one of the more difficult and time consuming courses I have taken at Yale, and it was by far one of the most rewarding!! Prof. Steinacker is AMAZING!!!!!!!
Definitely

Physics 180 is undoubtedly an extremely difficult class, but if you want to take physics at Yale, I would very strongly recommend it. The problem sets are a lot of work every week, but if you start early and go to peer tutoring/office hours they are totally doable. Similarly, the exams can seem a little overwhelming, but re-doing/studying the problem sets and lecture examples makes it much easier. Professor Steinacker is wonderful -- I could not have asked for a better professor. She is very friendly, offers an incredible amount of help (both through her, other professors, TFs, and peer tutors), and assumes no prior knowledge of physics (yet the class is hard enough that everyone must work). Again, if are taking physics at Yale, I would totally recommend Physics 180.
you're probably taking physics as a prereq for your major/ pre-med, but prof Steinacker is incredible, and made this class enjoyable!
Yes!
Yes, it's not too bad and pays dividends.
This is a really difficult course in my opinion, but you probably have to take it. Prof. Steinacker makes it bearable. She is the reason I chose 180 over 170.

Yes, I think it's a good class. I learned a lot, but certainly challenging. You likely do not have a choice, but go with it and hope for the best. Just be prepared to devote a lot of time to the course.
I would recommend this course because it is very interesting, as well as helpful when it comes to thinking of solutions to any problem in general.

Yes, as this is a class where the problem sets push your thinking, making you apply what you learn in class to situations you've never seen before. I most likely will end up majoring in the humanities, but I saw this as a valuable course to take.

If you have to take it then sure but if not then dont put yourself through all of the hours struggling to complete the problems sets in time. Steinecker certainly makes it much better but unless you love physics it will be tough.
If it is required I would suggest you take it
Yes, this course gives a great introduction to physics

Professor Steinacker is an incredible instructor!  Her lectures and clear and focused, and her examples problems and demonstrations are both very useful.  The homeworks successfully reinforced concepts used in class and were very helpful in reviewing for exams.

This is a good course in introductory physics and gives a good intuition for physics. It is a fairly large time commitment, however, as problem sets take a long time and are often challenging. If you have taken physics in high school, consider taking physics 200 instead as it will likely be more interesting.

Take it if you're interested in introductory college physics and how the world works. Also, this course serves as a prerequisite for many engineering/pre-med requirements so you'll have to take it anyway. It's a good course overall and be sure to put in the work!

I think this class is a lot of work, especially if you don't have a strong math or physics background. There are ample opportunities to get help. Unless you are tremendous at physics, you will likely need help from others to complete the problem set.
If you enjoy physics and can keep up with the problem sets, then yes.

I would recommend Physics 180 with Professor Steinacker to any qualified student with even the slightest interest in physics or an appreciation for math or problem-solving. Professor Steinacker is an amazing lecturer and she makes it fun and challenging for everyone. I took AP Physics B in high school, so maybe 65% of the topics were familiar, just with the addition of calculus, but the class was still challenging-- in a good way. The problem sets were kind of grueling (~10 hours/week and you need to do them in a group or (sometimes and) at office hours/study hall) but there is lots of help available and the problems were usually pretty satisfying to finally crack. The tests were also hard but we were able to do corrections, which was generous and very cathartic.

This is a very demanding course, but one of the best introduction courses I've taken. I would recommend to students who have a strong math background or willingness to develop their math skills because the course assumes students are strong in math.
